     378                 :            : /**
     379                 :            : * Checks to avoid mempool polluting consensus critical paths since cached
     380                 :            : * signature and script validity results will be reused if we validate this
     381                 :            : * transaction again during block validation.
     382                 :            : * */

     392   [ +  +  +  - ]:     131479 :     for (const CTxIn& txin : tx.vin) {

     394                 :            :

     485                 :            :     // Run the policy checks on a given transaction, excluding any script checks.
     486                 :            :     // Looks up inputs, calculates feerate, considers replacement, evaluates
     487                 :            :     // package limits, etc. As this function can be invoked for "free" by a peer,
     488                 :            :     // only tests that are fast should be done here (to avoid CPU DoS).
     489                 :            :     bool PreChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     490                 :            : 
     491                 :            :     // Run the script checks using our policy flags. As this can be slow, we should
     492                 :            :     // only invoke this on transactions that have otherwise passed policy checks.
     493                 :            :     bool PolicyScriptChecks(const ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws, PrecomputedTransactionData& txdata) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);

     495                 :            :     // Re-run the script checks, using consensus flags, and try to cache the
     496                 :            :     // result in the scriptcache. This should be done after
     497                 :            :     // PolicyScriptChecks(). This requires that all inputs either be in our
     498                 :            :     // utxo set or in the mempool.

     605                 :            :                 // Allow opt-out of transaction replacement by setting
     606                 :            :                 // nSequence > MAX_BIP125_RBF_SEQUENCE (SEQUENCE_FINAL-2) on all inputs.
     607                 :            :                 //
     608                 :            :                 // SEQUENCE_FINAL-1 is picked to still allow use of nLockTime by
     609                 :            :                 // non-replaceable transactions. All inputs rather than just one
     610                 :            :                 // is for the sake of multi-party protocols, where we don't
     611                 :            :                 // want a single party to be able to disable replacement.
     612                 :            :                 //
     613                 :            :                 // Transactions that don't explicitly signal replaceability are
     614                 :            :                 // *not* replaceable with the current logic, even if one of their
     615                 :            :                 // unconfirmed ancestors signals replaceability. This diverges
     616                 :            :                 // from BIP125's inherited signaling description (see CVE-2021-31876).
     617                 :            :                 // Applications relying on first-seen mempool behavior should
     618                 :            :                 // check all unconfirmed ancestors; otherwise an opt-in ancestor
     619                 :            :                 // might be replaced, causing removal of this descendant.

     724         [ +  - ]:      91646 :     const CTxMemPool::setEntries setIterConflicting = m_pool.GetIterSet(setConflicts);
     725                 :            :     // Calculate in-mempool ancestors, up to a limit.
     726         [ +  + ]:      91646 :     if (setConflicts.size() == 1) {
     727                 :            :         // In general, when we receive an RBF transaction with mempool conflicts, we want to know whether we
     728                 :            :         // would meet the chain limits after the conflicts have been removed. However, there isn't a practical
     729                 :            :         // way to do this short of calculating the ancestor and descendant sets with an overlay cache of
     730                 :            :         // changed mempool entries. Due to both implementation and runtime complexity concerns, this isn't
     731                 :            :         // very realistic, thus we only ensure a limited set of transactions are RBF'able despite mempool
     732                 :            :         // conflicts here. Importantly, we need to ensure that some transactions which were accepted using
     733                 :            :         // the below carve-out are able to be RBF'ed, without impacting the security the carve-out provides
     734                 :            :         // for off-chain contract systems (see link in the comment below).
     735                 :            :         //
     736                 :            :         // Specifically, the subset of RBF transactions which we allow despite chain limits are those which
     737                 :            :         // conflict directly with exactly one other transaction (but may evict children of said transaction),
     738                 :            :         // and which are not adding any new mempool dependencies. Note that the "no new mempool dependencies"
     739                 :            :         // check is accomplished later, so we don't bother doing anything about it here, but if BIP 125 is
     740                 :            :         // amended, we may need to move that check to here instead of removing it wholesale.
     741                 :            :         //
     742                 :            :         // Such transactions are clearly not merging any existing packages, so we are only concerned with
     743                 :            :         // ensuring that (a) no package is growing past the package size (not count) limits and (b) we are
     744                 :            :         // not allowing something to effectively use the (below) carve-out spot when it shouldn't be allowed
     745                 :            :         // to.
     746                 :            :         //
     747                 :            :         // To check these we first check if we meet the RBF criteria, above, and increment the descendant
     748                 :            :         // limits by the direct conflict and its descendants (as these are recalculated in
     749                 :            :         // CalculateMempoolAncestors by assuming the new transaction being added is a new descendant, with no
     750                 :            :         // removals, of each parent's existing dependent set). The ancestor count limits are unmodified (as
     751                 :            :         // the ancestor limits should be the same for both our new transaction and any conflicts).
     752                 :            :         // We don't bother incrementing m_limit_descendants by the full removal count as that limit never comes
     753                 :            :         // into force here (as we're only adding a single transaction).
     754         [ +  - ]:      33223 :         assert(setIterConflicting.size() == 1);
     755                 :      33223 :         CTxMemPool::txiter conflict = *setIterConflicting.begin();
     756                 :            : 
     757                 :      33223 :         m_limit_descendants += 1;
     758         [ +  - ]:      33223 :         m_limit_descendant_size += conflict->GetSizeWithDescendants();
     759                 :      33223 :     }
     760                 :            : 
     761                 :      91646 :     std::string errString;
     762   [ +  -  +  + ]:      91646 :     if (!m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, setAncestors, m_limit_ancestors, m_limit_ancestor_size, m_limit_descendants, m_limit_descendant_size, errString)) {
     763                 :      31121 :         setAncestors.clear();
     764                 :            :         // If CalculateMemPoolAncestors fails second time, we want the original error string.
     765                 :      31121 :         std::string dummy_err_string;
     766                 :            :         // Contracting/payment channels CPFP carve-out:
     767                 :            :         // If the new transaction is relatively small (up to 40k weight)
     768                 :            :         // and has at most one ancestor (ie ancestor limit of 2, including
     769                 :            :         // the new transaction), allow it if its parent has exactly the
     770                 :            :         // descendant limit descendants.
     771                 :            :         //
     772                 :            :         // This allows protocols which rely on distrusting counterparties
     773                 :            :         // being able to broadcast descendants of an unconfirmed transaction
     774                 :            :         // to be secure by simply only having two immediately-spendable
     775                 :            :         // outputs - one for each counterparty. For more info on the uses for
     776                 :            :         // this, see https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2018-November/016518.html
     777   [ +  +  +  + ]:      51857 :         if (nSize >  EXTRA_DESCENDANT_TX_SIZE_LIMIT ||
     778         [ +  - ]:      20736 :                 !m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, setAncestors, 2, m_limit_ancestor_size, m_limit_descendants + 1, m_limit_descendant_size + EXTRA_DESCENDANT_TX_SIZE_LIMIT, dummy_err_string)) {
     779   [ +  -  +  - ]:      25047 :             return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "too-long-mempool-chain", errString);
     780                 :            :         }
     781         [ +  + ]:      31121 :     }
     782                 :            : 
     783                 :            :     // A transaction that spends outputs that would be replaced by it is invalid. Now
     784                 :            :     // that we have the set of all ancestors we can detect this
     785                 :            :     // pathological case by making sure setConflicts and setAncestors don't
     786                 :            :     // intersect.
     787   [ +  +  +  + ]:      99799 :     for (CTxMemPool::txiter ancestorIt : setAncestors)

     799                 :            :     // Check if it's economically rational to mine this transaction rather

     806                 :            :     // subsequent RemoveStaged() and addUnchecked() calls don't guarantee

     811         [ +  - ]:      17528 :         CFeeRate newFeeRate(nModifiedFees, nSize);

     813                 :      17528 :         const int maxDescendantsToVisit = 100;
     814   [ +  +  +  + ]:      35605 :         for (const auto& mi : setIterConflicting) {
     815                 :            :             // Don't allow the replacement to reduce the feerate of the
     816                 :            :             // mempool.
     817                 :            :             //
     818                 :            :             // We usually don't want to accept replacements with lower
     819                 :            :             // feerates than what they replaced as that would lower the
     820                 :            :             // feerate of the next block. Requiring that the feerate always
     821                 :            :             // be increased is also an easy-to-reason about way to prevent
     822                 :            :             // DoS attacks via replacements.
     823                 :            :             //
     824                 :            :             // We only consider the feerates of transactions being directly
     825                 :            :             // replaced, not their indirect descendants. While that does
     826                 :            :             // mean high feerate children are ignored when deciding whether
     827                 :            :             // or not to replace, we do require the replacement to pay more
     828                 :            :             // overall fees too, mitigating most cases.
     829   [ +  -  +  -  :      18077 :             CFeeRate oldFeeRate(mi->GetModifiedFee(), mi->GetTxSize());
             +  -  +  - ]
     830         [ +  + ]:      18077 :             if (newFeeRate <= oldFeeRate)
     831                 :            :             {
     832   [ +  -  +  - ]:      22286 :                 return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "insufficient fee",
     833         [ +  - ]:      22286 :                         strprintf("rejecting replacement %s; new feerate %s <= old feerate %s",
     834         [ +  - ]:      11143 :                             hash.ToString(),
     835         [ +  - ]:      11143 :                             newFeeRate.ToString(),

     838                 :            :

     942                 :      30454 : bool MemPoolAccept::ConsensusScriptChecks(const ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws, PrecomputedTransactionData& txdata)
     943                 :            : {
     944                 :      30454 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
     945                 :      30454 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
     946                 :      30454 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;
     947                 :      30454 :     const CChainParams& chainparams = args.m_chainparams;
     948                 :            : 
     949                 :            :     // Check again against the current block tip's script verification
     950                 :            :     // flags to cache our script execution flags. This is, of course,
     951                 :            :     // useless if the next block has different script flags from the
     952                 :            :     // previous one, but because the cache tracks script flags for us it
     953                 :            :     // will auto-invalidate and we'll just have a few blocks of extra
     954                 :            :     // misses on soft-fork activation.
     955                 :            :     //
     956                 :            :     // This is also useful in case of bugs in the standard flags that cause
     957                 :            :     // transactions to pass as valid when they're actually invalid. For
     958                 :            :     // instance the STRICTENC flag was incorrectly allowing certain
     959                 :            :     // CHECKSIG NOT scripts to pass, even though they were invalid.
     960                 :            :     //
     961                 :            :     // There is a similar check in CreateNewBlock() to prevent creating
     962                 :            :     // invalid blocks (using TestBlockValidity), however allowing such
     963                 :            :     // transactions into the mempool can be exploited as a DoS attack.
     964                 :      30454 :     unsigned int currentBlockScriptVerifyFlags = GetBlockScriptFlags(m_active_chainstate.m_chain.Tip(), chainparams.GetConsensus());
     965         [ +  - ]:      30454 :     if (!CheckInputsFromMempoolAndCache(tx, state, m_view, m_pool, currentBlockScriptVerifyFlags, txdata, m_active_chainstate.CoinsTip())) {

     967         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 __func__, hash.ToString(), state.ToString());
     968                 :            :     }
     969                 :            : 
     970                 :      30454 :     return true;
     971                 :      30454 : }

    1050                 :     159596 : PackageMempoolAcceptResult MemPoolAccept::AcceptMultipleTransactions(const std::vector<CTransactionRef>& txns, ATMPArgs& args)
    1051                 :            : {

    1053                 :            :

    1375                 :        180 : static CuckooCache::cache<uint256, SignatureCacheHasher> g_scriptExecutionCache;

    1378                 :       1145 : void InitScriptExecutionCache() {
    1379                 :            :     // Setup the salted hasher
    1380                 :       1145 :     uint256 nonce = GetRandHash();
    1381                 :            :     // We want the nonce to be 64 bytes long to force the hasher to process
    1382                 :            :     // this chunk, which makes later hash computations more efficient. We
    1383                 :            :     // just write our 32-byte entropy twice to fill the 64 bytes.
    1384                 :       1145 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1385                 :       1145 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1386                 :            :     // nMaxCacheSize is unsigned. If -maxsigcachesize is set to zero,
    1387                 :            :     // setup_bytes creates the minimum possible cache (2 elements).
    1388   [ +  -  +  - ]:       1145 :     size_t nMaxCacheSize = std::min(std::max((int64_t)0, gArgs.GetArg("-maxsigcachesize", DEFAULT_MAX_SIG_CACHE_SIZE) / 2), MAX_MAX_SIG_CACHE_SIZE) * ((size_t) 1 << 20);

    1394                 :            : /**
    1395                 :            :  * Check whether all of this transaction's input scripts succeed.
    1396                 :            :  *
    1397                 :            :  * This involves ECDSA signature checks so can be computationally intensive. This function should
    1398                 :            :  * only be called after the cheap sanity checks in CheckTxInputs passed.
    1399                 :            :  *
    1400                 :            :  * If pvChecks is not nullptr, script checks are pushed onto it instead of being performed inline. Any
    1401                 :            :  * script checks which are not necessary (eg due to script execution cache hits) are, obviously,
    1402                 :            :  * not pushed onto pvChecks/run.
    1403                 :            :  *
    1404                 :            :  * Setting cacheSigStore/cacheFullScriptStore to false will remove elements from the corresponding cache
    1405                 :            :  * which are matched. This is useful for checking blocks where we will likely never need the cache
    1406                 :            :  * entry again.
    1407                 :            :  *
    1408                 :            :  * Note that we may set state.reason to NOT_STANDARD for extra soft-fork flags in flags, block-checking
    1409                 :            :  * callers should probably reset it to CONSENSUS in such cases.
    1410                 :            :  *
    1411                 :            :  * Non-static (and re-declared) in src/test/txvalidationcache_tests.cpp
    1412                 :            :  */
    1413                 :      91982 : bool CheckInputScripts(const CTransaction& tx, TxValidationState& state,
    1414                 :            :                        const CCoinsViewCache& inputs, unsigned int flags, bool cacheSigStore,

    1697                 :            :  *  Validity checks that depend on the UTXO set are also done; ConnectBlock()
    1698                 :            :  *  can fail if those validity checks fail (among other reasons). */
    1699                 :      27500 : bool CChainState::ConnectBlock(const CBlock& block, BlockValidationState& state, CBlockIndex* pindex,
    1700                 :            :                                CCoinsViewCache& view, bool fJustCheck)
    1701                 :            : {
    1702                 :      27500 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1703         [ +  - ]:      27500 :     assert(pindex);
    1704         [ +  - ]:      27500 :     assert(*pindex->phashBlock == block.GetHash());
    1705                 :      27500 :     int64_t nTimeStart = GetTimeMicros();
    1706                 :            : 
    1707                 :            :     // Check it again in case a previous version let a bad block in
    1708                 :            :     // NOTE: We don't currently (re-)invoke ContextualCheckBlock() or
    1709                 :            :     // ContextualCheckBlockHeader() here. This means that if we add a new
    1710                 :            :     // consensus rule that is enforced in one of those two functions, then we
    1711                 :            :     // may have let in a block that violates the rule prior to updating the
    1712                 :            :     // software, and we would NOT be enforcing the rule here. Fully solving
    1713                 :            :     // upgrade from one software version to the next after a consensus rule
    1714                 :            :     // change is potentially tricky and issue-specific (see NeedsRedownload()
    1715                 :            :     // for one approach that was used for BIP 141 deployment).
    1716                 :            :     // Also, currently the rule against blocks more than 2 hours in the future
    1717                 :            :     // is enforced in ContextualCheckBlockHeader(); we wouldn't want to
    1718                 :            :     // re-enforce that rule here (at least until we make it impossible for
    1719                 :            :     // GetAdjustedTime() to go backward).
    1720         [ +  - ]:      27500 :     if (!CheckBlock(block, state, m_params.GetConsensus(), !fJustCheck, !fJustCheck)) {
    1721         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (state.GetResult() == BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED) {
    1722                 :            :             // We don't write down blocks to disk if they may have been
    1723                 :            :             // corrupted, so this should be impossible unless we're having hardware
    1724                 :            :             // problems.
    1725   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             return AbortNode(state, "Corrupt block found indicating potential hardware failure; shutting down");

    1727         [ #  # ]:          0 :         return error("%s: Consensus::CheckBlock: %s", __func__, state.ToString());

    1745         [ +  - ]:      26365 :     if (!hashAssumeValid.IsNull()) {

    1747                 :            :         // A suitable default value is included with the software and updated from time to time.  Because validity
    1748                 :            :         //  relative to a piece of software is an objective fact these defaults can be easily reviewed.
    1749                 :            :         // This setting doesn't force the selection of any particular chain but makes validating some faster by
    1750                 :            :         //  effectively caching the result of part of the verification.

    1755                 :          0 :                 pindexBestHeader->nChainWork >= nMinimumChainWork) {
    1756                 :            :                 // This block is a member of the assumed verified chain and an ancestor of the best header.
    1757                 :            :                 // Script verification is skipped when connecting blocks under the
    1758                 :            :                 // assumevalid block. Assuming the assumevalid block is valid this
    1759                 :            :                 // is safe because block merkle hashes are still computed and checked,
    1760                 :            :                 // Of course, if an assumed valid block is invalid due to false scriptSigs
    1761                 :            :                 // this optimization would allow an invalid chain to be accepted.
    1762                 :            :                 // The equivalent time check discourages hash power from extorting the network via DOS attack
    1763                 :            :                 //  into accepting an invalid block through telling users they must manually set assumevalid.
    1764                 :            :                 //  Requiring a software change or burying the invalid block, regardless of the setting, makes
    1765                 :            :                 //  it hard to hide the implication of the demand.  This also avoids having release candidates
    1766                 :            :                 //  that are hardly doing any signature verification at all in testing without having to
    1767                 :            :                 //  artificially set the default assumed verified block further back.
    1768                 :            :                 // The test against nMinimumChainWork prevents the skipping when denied access to any chain at
    1769                 :            :                 //  least as good as the expected chain.
    1770                 :          0 :                 fScriptChecks = (GetBlockProofEquivalentTime(*pindexBestHeader, *pindex, *pindexBestHeader, m_params.GetConsensus()) <= 60 * 60 * 24 * 7 * 2);
    1771                 :          0 :             }
    1772                 :            :         }
    1773                 :          0 :     }
    1774                 :            : 
    1775                 :      26365 :     int64_t nTime1 = GetTimeMicros(); nTimeCheck += nTime1 - nTimeStart;
    1776   [ +  +  +  -  :      26365 :     LogPrint(BCLog::BENCH, "    - Sanity checks: %.2fms [%.2fs (%.2fms/blk)]\n", MILLI * (nTime1 - nTimeStart), nTimeCheck * MICRO, nTimeCheck * MILLI / nBlocksTotal);
             +  -  +  - ]
    1777                 :            : 
    1778                 :            :     // Do not allow blocks that contain transactions which 'overwrite' older transactions,
    1779                 :            :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    1780                 :            :     // If such overwrites are allowed, coinbases and transactions depending upon those
    1781                 :            :     // can be duplicated to remove the ability to spend the first instance -- even after
    1782                 :            :     // being sent to another address.
    1783                 :            :     // See BIP30, CVE-2012-1909, and http://r6.ca/blog/20120206T005236Z.html for more information.
    1784                 :            :     // This logic is not necessary for memory pool transactions, as AcceptToMemoryPool
    1785                 :            :     // already refuses previously-known transaction ids entirely.
    1786                 :            :     // This rule was originally applied to all blocks with a timestamp after March 15, 2012, 0:00 UTC.
    1787                 :            :     // Now that the whole chain is irreversibly beyond that time it is applied to all blocks except the
    1788                 :            :     // two in the chain that violate it. This prevents exploiting the issue against nodes during their
    1789                 :            :     // initial block download.
    1790   [ -  +  #  # ]:      52730 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !((pindex->nHeight==91842 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256S("0x00000000000a4d0a398161ffc163c503763b1f4360639393e0e4c8e300e0caec")) ||
    1791         [ -  + ]:      26365 :                            (pindex->nHeight==91880 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256S("0x00000000000743f190a18c5577a3c2d2a1f610ae9601ac046a38084ccb7cd721")));
    1792                 :            : 
    1793                 :            :     // Once BIP34 activated it was not possible to create new duplicate coinbases and thus other than starting
    1794                 :            :     // with the 2 existing duplicate coinbase pairs, not possible to create overwriting txs.  But by the
    1795                 :            :     // time BIP34 activated, in each of the existing pairs the duplicate coinbase had overwritten the first
    1796                 :            :     // before the first had been spent.  Since those coinbases are sufficiently buried it's no longer possible to create further
    1797                 :            :     // duplicate transactions descending from the known pairs either.
    1798                 :            :     // If we're on the known chain at height greater than where BIP34 activated, we can save the db accesses needed for the BIP30 check.
    1799                 :            : 
    1800                 :            :     // BIP34 requires that a block at height X (block X) has its coinbase
    1801                 :            :     // scriptSig start with a CScriptNum of X (indicated height X).  The above
    1802                 :            :     // logic of no longer requiring BIP30 once BIP34 activates is flawed in the
    1803                 :            :     // case that there is a block X before the BIP34 height of 227,931 which has
    1804                 :            :     // an indicated height Y where Y is greater than X.  The coinbase for block
    1805                 :            :     // X would also be a valid coinbase for block Y, which could be a BIP30
    1806                 :            :     // violation.  An exhaustive search of all mainnet coinbases before the
    1807                 :            :     // BIP34 height which have an indicated height greater than the block height
    1808                 :            :     // reveals many occurrences. The 3 lowest indicated heights found are
    1809                 :            :     // 209,921, 490,897, and 1,983,702 and thus coinbases for blocks at these 3
    1810                 :            :     // heights would be the first opportunity for BIP30 to be violated.
    1811                 :            : 
    1812                 :            :     // The search reveals a great many blocks which have an indicated height
    1813                 :            :     // greater than 1,983,702, so we simply remove the optimization to skip
    1814                 :            :     // BIP30 checking for blocks at height 1,983,702 or higher.  Before we reach
    1815                 :            :     // that block in another 25 years or so, we should take advantage of a
    1816                 :            :     // future consensus change to do a new and improved version of BIP34 that
    1817                 :            :     // will actually prevent ever creating any duplicate coinbases in the
    1818                 :            :     // future.
    1819                 :            :     static constexpr int BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT = 1983702;
    1820                 :            : 
    1821                 :            :     // There is no potential to create a duplicate coinbase at block 209,921
    1822                 :            :     // because this is still before the BIP34 height and so explicit BIP30
    1823                 :            :     // checking is still active.
    1824                 :            : 
    1825                 :            :     // The final case is block 176,684 which has an indicated height of
    1826                 :            :     // 490,897. Unfortunately, this issue was not discovered until about 2 weeks
    1827                 :            :     // before block 490,897 so there was not much opportunity to address this
    1828                 :            :     // case other than to carefully analyze it and determine it would not be a
    1829                 :            :     // problem. Block 490,897 was, in fact, mined with a different coinbase than
    1830                 :            :     // block 176,684, but it is important to note that even if it hadn't been or
    1831                 :            :     // is remined on an alternate fork with a duplicate coinbase, we would still
    1832                 :            :     // not run into a BIP30 violation.  This is because the coinbase for 176,684
    1833                 :            :     // is spent in block 185,956 in transaction
    1834                 :            :     // d4f7fbbf92f4a3014a230b2dc70b8058d02eb36ac06b4a0736d9d60eaa9e8781.  This
    1835                 :            :     // spending transaction can't be duplicated because it also spends coinbase
    1836                 :            :     // 0328dd85c331237f18e781d692c92de57649529bd5edf1d01036daea32ffde29.  This
    1837                 :            :     // coinbase has an indicated height of over 4.2 billion, and wouldn't be
    1838                 :            :     // duplicatable until that height, and it's currently impossible to create a
    1839                 :            :     // chain that long. Nevertheless we may wish to consider a future soft fork
    1840                 :            :     // which retroactively prevents block 490,897 from creating a duplicate
    1841                 :            :     // coinbase. The two historical BIP30 violations often provide a confusing
    1842                 :            :     // edge case when manipulating the UTXO and it would be simpler not to have
    1843                 :            :     // another edge case to deal with.
    1844                 :            : 
    1845                 :            :     // testnet3 has no blocks before the BIP34 height with indicated heights
    1846                 :            :     // post BIP34 before approximately height 486,000,000 and presumably will
    1847                 :            :     // be reset before it reaches block 1,983,702 and starts doing unnecessary
    1848                 :            :     // BIP30 checking again.
    1849         [ +  - ]:      26365 :     assert(pindex->pprev);
    1850                 :      26365 :     CBlockIndex* pindexBIP34height = pindex->pprev->GetAncestor(m_params.GetConsensus().BIP34Height);
    1851                 :            :     //Only continue to enforce if we're below BIP34 activation height or the block hash at that height doesn't correspond.
    1852   [ +  -  -  + ]:      26365 :     fEnforceBIP30 = fEnforceBIP30 && (!pindexBIP34height || !(pindexBIP34height->GetBlockHash() == m_params.GetConsensus().BIP34Hash));

    1854                 :            :     // TODO: Remove BIP30 checking from block height 1,983,702 on, once we have a

    1856                 :            :     // duplicate earlier coinbases.
    1857   [ +  -  #  # ]:      26365 :     if (fEnforceBIP30 || pindex->nHeight >= BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT) {
    1858   [ +  +  +  - ]:      67865 :         for (const auto& tx : block.vtx) {

    2032                 :            : 
    2033                 :     832197 : bool CChainState::FlushStateToDisk(
    2034                 :            :     BlockValidationState &state,
    2035                 :            :     FlushStateMode mode,
    2036                 :            :     int nManualPruneHeight)
    2037                 :            : {
    2038                 :     832197 :     LOCK(cs_main);
    2039         [ +  - ]:     832197 :     assert(this->CanFlushToDisk());
    2040                 :            :     static std::chrono::microseconds nLastWrite{0};
    2041                 :            :     static std::chrono::microseconds nLastFlush{0};
    2042                 :     832197 :     std::set<int> setFilesToPrune;
    2043                 :            :     bool full_flush_completed = false;
    2044                 :            : 
    2045         [ +  - ]:     832197 :     const size_t coins_count = CoinsTip().GetCacheSize();

    2047                 :            :

    2049                 :            :     {
    2050                 :     832197 :         bool fFlushForPrune = false;

    2333                 :       8735 :         blocksConnected.emplace_back();
    2334                 :       8735 :     }
    2335                 :            : 
    2336                 :       8735 :     std::vector<PerBlockConnectTrace>& GetBlocksConnected() {
    2337                 :            :         // We always keep one extra block at the end of our list because
    2338                 :            :         // blocks are added after all the conflicted transactions have
    2339                 :            :         // been filled in. Thus, the last entry should always be an empty
    2340                 :            :         // one waiting for the transactions from the next block. We pop
    2341                 :            :         // the last entry here to make sure the list we return is sane.
    2342         [ +  - ]:       8735 :         assert(!blocksConnected.back().pindex);
    2343                 :       8735 :         blocksConnected.pop_back();
    2344                 :       8735 :         return blocksConnected;
    2345                 :            :     }
    2346                 :            : };

    2616                 :      93371 : bool CChainState::ActivateBestChain(BlockValidationState& state, std::shared_ptr<const CBlock> pblock)
    2617                 :            : {
    2618                 :            :     // Note that while we're often called here from ProcessNewBlock, this is
    2619                 :            :     // far from a guarantee. Things in the P2P/RPC will often end up calling
    2620                 :            :     // us in the middle of ProcessNewBlock - do not assume pblock is set
    2621                 :            :     // sanely for performance or correctness!
    2622                 :      93371 :     AssertLockNotHeld(cs_main);
    2623                 :            : 
    2624                 :            :     // ABC maintains a fair degree of expensive-to-calculate internal state
    2625                 :            :     // because this function periodically releases cs_main so that it does not lock up other threads for too long
    2626                 :            :     // during large connects - and to allow for e.g. the callback queue to drain
    2627                 :            :     // we use m_cs_chainstate to enforce mutual exclusion so that only one caller may execute this function at a time
    2628                 :      93371 :     LOCK(m_cs_chainstate);

    2634                 :            :         // Block until the validation queue drains. This should largely
    2635                 :            :         // never happen in normal operation, however may happen during
    2636                 :            :         // reindex, causing memory blowup if we run too far ahead.
    2637                 :            :         // Note that if a validationinterface callback ends up calling

    3226                 :            :         }
    3227         [ #  # ]:          0 :     }
    3228                 :            : 
    3229                 :            :     // Validation for witness commitments.
    3230                 :            :     // * We compute the witness hash (which is the hash including witnesses) of all the block's transactions, except the
    3231                 :            :     //   coinbase (where 0x0000....0000 is used instead).
    3232                 :            :     // * The coinbase scriptWitness is a stack of a single 32-byte vector, containing a witness reserved value (unconstrained).
    3233                 :            :     // * We build a merkle tree with all those witness hashes as leaves (similar to the hashMerkleRoot in the block header).
    3234                 :            :     // * There must be at least one output whose scriptPubKey is a single 36-byte push, the first 4 bytes of which are
    3235                 :            :     //   {0xaa, 0x21, 0xa9, 0xed}, and the following 32 bytes are SHA256^2(witness root, witness reserved value). In case there are
    3236                 :            :     //   multiple, the last one is used.
    3237                 :      26365 :     bool fHaveWitness = false;
    3238         [ +  - ]:      26365 :     if (DeploymentActiveAfter(pindexPrev, consensusParams, Consensus::DEPLOYMENT_SEGWIT)) {
    3239                 :      26365 :         int commitpos = GetWitnessCommitmentIndex(block);
    3240         [ +  - ]:      26365 :         if (commitpos != NO_WITNESS_COMMITMENT) {
    3241                 :      26365 :             bool malleated = false;
    3242                 :      26365 :             uint256 hashWitness = BlockWitnessMerkleRoot(block, &malleated);
    3243                 :            :             // The malleation check is ignored; as the transaction tree itself
    3244                 :            :             // already does not permit it, it is impossible to trigger in the
    3245                 :            :             // witness tree.
    3246   [ -  +  -  + ]:      26365 :             if (block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack.size() != 1 || block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack[0].size() != 32) {

             #  #  +  - ]
    3248                 :            :             }
    3249                 :      26365 :             CHash256().Write(hashWitness).Write(block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack[0]).Finalize(hashWitness);
    3250         [ -  + ]:      26365 :             if (memcmp(hashWitness.begin(), &block.vtx[0]->vout[commitpos].scriptPubKey[6], 32)) {
    3251   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                 return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED, "bad-witness-merkle-match", strprintf("%s : witness merkle commitment mismatch", __func__));
                   #  # ]

    3253                 :            :             fHaveWitness = true;
    3254         [ +  - ]:      26365 :         }
    3255                 :      26365 :     }
    3256                 :            : 
    3257                 :            :     // No witness data is allowed in blocks that don't commit to witness data, as this would otherwise leave room for spam

    3263                 :          0 :         }

    3268                 :            :     // coinbase witness, it would be possible for the weight to be too

    3317                 :            : 
    3318                 :            :         /* Determine if this block descends from any block which has been found
    3319                 :            :          * invalid (m_failed_blocks), then mark pindexPrev and any blocks between
    3320                 :            :          * them as failed. For example:
    3321                 :            :          *
    3322                 :            :          *                D3
    3323                 :            :          *              /
    3324                 :            :          *      B2 - C2
    3325                 :            :          *    /         \
    3326                 :            :          *  A             D2 - E2 - F2
    3327                 :            :          *    \
    3328                 :            :          *      B1 - C1 - D1 - E1
    3329                 :            :          *
    3330                 :            :          * In the case that we attempted to reorg from E1 to F2, only to find
    3331                 :            :          * C2 to be invalid, we would mark D2, E2, and F2 as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD
    3332                 :            :          * but NOT D3 (it was not in any of our candidate sets at the time).
    3333                 :            :          *
    3334                 :            :          * In any case D3 will also be marked as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD at restart
    3335                 :            :          * in LoadBlockIndex.
    3336                 :            :          */
    3337         [ +  + ]:     206928 :         if (!pindexPrev->IsValid(BLOCK_VALID_SCRIPTS)) {
    3338                 :            :             // The above does not mean "invalid": it checks if the previous block
    3339                 :            :             // hasn't been validated up to BLOCK_VALID_SCRIPTS. This is a performance
    3340                 :            :             // optimization, in the common case of adding a new block to the tip,
    3341                 :            :             // we don't need to iterate over the failed blocks list.
    3342   [ -  +  +  - ]:     199182 :             for (const CBlockIndex* failedit : m_failed_blocks) {
    3343         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 if (pindexPrev->GetAncestor(failedit->nHeight) == failedit) {
    3344         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     assert(failedit->nStatus & BLOCK_FAILED_VALID);
    3345                 :          0 :                     CBlockIndex* invalid_walk = pindexPrev;
    3346         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     while (invalid_walk != failedit) {
    3347                 :          0 :                         invalid_walk->nStatus |= BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD;
    3348                 :          0 :                         setDirtyBlockIndex.insert(invalid_walk);
    3349                 :          0 :                         invalid_walk = invalid_walk->pprev;
    3350                 :            :                     }
    3351   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                     LogPrintf("ERROR: %s: prev block invalid\n", __func__);
                   #  # ]
    3352   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :                     return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_INVALID_PREV, "bad-prevblk");
                   #  # ]
    3353                 :          0 :                 }
    3354                 :          0 :             }

    3356         [ +  + ]:     220815 :     }

    3996                 :          0 : bool CChainState::ReplayBlocks()
    3997                 :            : {
    3998                 :          0 :     LOCK(cs_main);
    3999                 :            : 
    4000                 :          0 :     CCoinsView& db = this->CoinsDB();
    4001         [ #  # ]:          0 :     CCoinsViewCache cache(&db);
    4002                 :            : 
    4003         [ #  # ]:          0 :     std::vector<uint256> hashHeads = db.GetHeadBlocks();
    4004         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (hashHeads.empty()) return true; // We're already in a consistent state.
    4005   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     if (hashHeads.size() != 2) return error("ReplayBlocks(): unknown inconsistent state");
    4006                 :            : 
    4007   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     uiInterface.ShowProgress(_("Replaying blocks").translated, 0, false);
    4008   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :     LogPrintf("Replaying blocks\n");
                   #  # ]
    4009                 :            : 
    4010                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexOld = nullptr;  // Old tip during the interrupted flush.
    4011                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexNew;            // New tip during the interrupted flush.
    4012                 :            :     const CBlockIndex* pindexFork = nullptr; // Latest block common to both the old and the new tip.
    4013                 :            : 
    4014   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     if (m_blockman.m_block_index.count(hashHeads[0]) == 0) {
    4015         [ #  # ]:          0 :         return error("ReplayBlocks(): reorganization to unknown block requested");
    4016                 :            :     }
    4017         [ #  # ]:          0 :     pindexNew = m_blockman.m_block_index[hashHeads[0]];
    4018                 :            : 
    4019         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!hashHeads[1].IsNull()) { // The old tip is allowed to be 0, indicating it's the first flush.
    4020   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         if (m_blockman.m_block_index.count(hashHeads[1]) == 0) {
    4021         [ #  # ]:          0 :             return error("ReplayBlocks(): reorganization from unknown block requested");
    4022                 :            :         }
    4023         [ #  # ]:          0 :         pindexOld = m_blockman.m_block_index[hashHeads[1]];
    4024         [ #  # ]:          0 :         pindexFork = LastCommonAncestor(pindexOld, pindexNew);
    4025         [ #  # ]:          0 :         assert(pindexFork != nullptr);
    4026                 :            :     }
    4027                 :            : 
    4028                 :            :     // Rollback along the old branch.
    4029         [ #  # ]:          0 :     while (pindexOld != pindexFork) {
    4030         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (pindexOld->nHeight > 0) { // Never disconnect the genesis block.
    4031         [ #  # ]:          0 :             CBlock block;
    4032   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (!ReadBlockFromDisk(block, pindexOld, m_params.GetConsensus())) {
    4033   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                 return error("RollbackBlock(): ReadBlockFromDisk() failed at %d, hash=%s", pindexOld->nHeight, pindexOld->GetBlockHash().ToString());
    4034                 :            :             }
    4035   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             LogPrintf("Rolling back %s (%i)\n", pindexOld->GetBlockHash().ToString(), pindexOld->nHeight);
             #  #  #  # ]
    4036         [ #  # ]:          0 :             DisconnectResult res = DisconnectBlock(block, pindexOld, cache);
    4037         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (res == DISCONNECT_FAILED) {
    4038   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                 return error("RollbackBlock(): DisconnectBlock failed at %d, hash=%s", pindexOld->nHeight, pindexOld->GetBlockHash().ToString());
    4039                 :            :             }
    4040                 :            :             // If DISCONNECT_UNCLEAN is returned, it means a non-existing UTXO was deleted, or an existing UTXO was
    4041                 :            :             // overwritten. It corresponds to cases where the block-to-be-disconnect never had all its operations
    4042                 :            :             // applied to the UTXO set. However, as both writing a UTXO and deleting a UTXO are idempotent operations,
    4043                 :            :             // the result is still a version of the UTXO set with the effects of that block undone.
    4044         [ #  # ]:          0 :         }
    4045                 :          0 :         pindexOld = pindexOld->pprev;
    4046                 :            :     }
    4047                 :            : 
    4048                 :            :     // Roll forward from the forking point to the new tip.
    4049         [ #  # ]:          0 :     int nForkHeight = pindexFork ? pindexFork->nHeight : 0;

    4732                 :         10 :         return false;
    4733                 :            :     }
    4734                 :            : 
    4735                 :            :     int64_t current_coinsdb_cache_size{0};
    4736                 :            :     int64_t current_coinstip_cache_size{0};
    4737                 :            : 
    4738                 :            :     // Cache percentages to allocate to each chainstate.
    4739                 :            :     //
    4740                 :            :     // These particular percentages don't matter so much since they will only be
    4741                 :            :     // relevant during snapshot activation; caches are rebalanced at the conclusion of
    4742                 :            :     // this function. We want to give (essentially) all available cache capacity to the
    4743                 :            :     // snapshot to aid the bulk load later in this function.
    4744                 :            :     static constexpr double IBD_CACHE_PERC = 0.01;
    4745                 :            :     static constexpr double SNAPSHOT_CACHE_PERC = 0.99;
    4746                 :            : 
    4747                 :            :     {
    4748                 :       1892 :         LOCK(::cs_main);
    4749                 :            :         // Resize the coins caches to ensure we're not exceeding memory limits.
    4750                 :            :         //
    4751                 :            :         // Allocate the majority of the cache to the incoming snapshot chainstate, since
    4752                 :            :         // (optimistically) getting to its tip will be the top priority. We'll need to call
    4753                 :            :         // `MaybeRebalanceCaches()` once we're done with this function to ensure
    4754                 :            :         // the right allocation (including the possibility that no snapshot was activated
    4755                 :            :         // and that we should restore the active chainstate caches to their original size).
    4756                 :            :         //
